asked the Minister of Plantation Industries:
(i) the extent of tea smallholdings in Sri Lanka in acres, separately on per district basis;
(ii) the volume of tea produced from those tea smallholdings annually;
(iii) the value of the subsidy given to tea smallholders; and
(iv) the steps that have been taken to increase tea production in Sri Lanka?
(b) If not, why? () ( ( ) ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Ramesh Pathirana) .
asked the Minister of Trade, Commerce and Food Security:
(i) the number of Multi-purpose Co-operative Societies established in Sri Lanka to date;
(ii) the number of Co-operative Rural Bank branches established under the aforesaid societies;
(iii) the number of customers in the aforesaid banking system; and
(iv) separately, the value of assets and liabilities of the aforesaid banking system?
(b) Will he also inform this House whether automated teller machines and debit card facilities are available for the Co-operative Rural Banking system?
(c) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Nalin Fernando) .

asked the Minister of Justice, Prisons Affairs and Constitutional Reforms:
(i) the categorization method of the detainees detained in the prisons of Sri Lanka;
(ii) separately, the quantity of meals provided for each of the aforementioned prisoners;
(iii) the current capacity existing for detainees in the prisons in Sri Lanka; and
(iv) the number of detainees detained in an overcrowded manner?
(b) If not, why? ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Anuradha Jayaratne - State Minister of Justice and Prison Affairs) .
asked the Minister of Women, Child Affairs and Social Empowerment:
(i) whether the Housing Development Programme implemented by the Department of Social Services for persons with disabilities, functions at present;
(ii) if so, the amount of money provided to a family to construct a house;
(iii) the number of persons to whom housing aid has been granted under that programme so far;
(iv) the number of families to which aid is granted in a year;
(v) whether the above programme would be continued in future; and
(vi) whether the amount of aid has been increased at present?
(b) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella, Attorney-at-Law) -

CONSTRUCTION OF CENTRAL EXPRESSWAY FROM RAMBUKKANA TO GALAGEDERA: CALL FOR TENDERS
asked the Minister of Transport and Highways:
(a) Will he inform this House of -
(i) the date on which tenders were called to construct the extent of 20 kilometres from Rambukkana to Galagedara on the Central Expressway;
(ii) the number and the names of local companies which have submitted tenders for this purpose along with the rates offered by them, separately;
(iii) the number and the names of foreign companies which have submitted tenders for this purpose along with the rates offered by them, separately; and
(iv) the measures that will be taken in relation to the allegations levelled against the malpractices that are said to have happened when this tender procedure was adopted?

(i) the reasons for spending only Rs. 20,000 out of the allocation of Rs. 5 million released by the Ministry of Environment to the Ministry of Public Services, Provincial Councils and Local Government in the year 2018 under the Parisara Mawatha Project for the selected provinces to establish Parisara Mawath;

(ii) the reasons for not providing a definition and for not introducing the criteria related to the Parisara Mawatha, in spite of the fact that it had been planned to establish 100 Parisara Mawath in the year 2021;
(iii) the reasons for not including the "Parisara Mawatha" Project in the Action Plan relevant to the year 2021 of the Ministry of Environment; and
(iv) the reasons for suspending the implementation of the said project without accomplishing the expected objectives of the "Parisara Mawatha" Project?
( ) (The Hon. Prasanna Ranatunga) Hon. Speaker, on behalf of the Minister of Environment, I table* the Answer.

been in operation only till 2017. Establishment of three eco-pathways were commenced mainly in Kamburupitiya, Kundasale and Wanathavilluwa in the year 2017 and although provisions pertaining to the eco- pathway belonging to the Kamburupitiya Pradeshiya Sabha (Rs. 2,000,000) was released on 04.07.2017, payments have not been made because when the plot of land identified for the construction of the eco-pathway was about to be approved, it was found that the land did not belong to the Pradeshiya Sabha.

Although provisions pertaining to the eco-pathway belonging to the Kundasale Pradeshiya Sabha (Rs. 1,995,690.80) was released on 30.10.2017, these amounts have not been paid as the project had not been
completed within the relevant period and imprests of the local authority concerned for the year 2017 had not been adequate.

Similarly, this Ministry released the provisions relevant to payments for the eco-pathway belonging to the Wanathavilluwa Pradeshiya Sabha on 17.11.2017 to the local authority concerned. The Ministry of Local Government has directed the relevant Local Government Commissioners to settle the approved bills relevant to the task before 20.12.2017 and obtain the money. The Wanathavilluwa Pradeshiya Sabha by its letter dated 08.02.2018 informed that the money had not been received for the task concerned and the Ministry of Local Government has stated that the relevant vouchers were received on 29.12.2017 and they have been retained due to inadequacy of imprests for the year 2017. Therefore, a request was made by the Ministry of Mahaweli Development and Environment in order to bear the extra expenditure for those payments through a note of request for authority and a sum of Rs. 911,065.05 was released to the local authority concerned on 14.09.2018 from the provisions remaining from the year 2018. (ii) The "Parisara Mawatha" Programme has not been included in the Action Plan for the year 2021 and plans have not been made to establish 100 eco-pathways. The concept note has introduced the eco-pathway as A pathway which has an appropriate canopy of flora about in the form of an arch, shade the fresh air with minimum impact of coarse architectural straight lines and from which other sufferings to people have been removed through relevant specific road laws.

(iii) As the "Parisara Mawatha" is a pilot project, provisions had been made available for it under a separate expenditure Head and no provisions have been made available in the year 2021 for this purpose.
(iv) The "Parisara Mawatha" Project has been suspended as provisions have not been received for the project.

( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) Next, the Hon. Vadivel Suresh. You have three minutes.
( ) (The Hon. Presiding Member) . ( ) (The Hon. Vadivel Suresh) . .

Hon. Presiding Member, we have defeated the most ruthless terrorist organization in the world about 14 years ago. "Terrorism", if you define, is massacring or killing the innocents to achieve a political aim. So, whether the cause for terrorism is justifiable or not, terrorism per se cannot be justified. And also, we know that terrorism is no more local or regional; it is global and transnational. Therefore, there should be a concise and concerted effort on the part of the international community to address that menace. But for a country like us, it does not happen that way. We crushed the LTTE, but the separatist Tamil diaspora is trying to achieve the aim which the LTTE could not achieve through terrorism. So, they are taking advantage of the electoral system to pressurize their MPs to issue anti-Sri Lankan statements under the guise of human rights.

Even the Canadian Prime Minister is making statements to please the Canadian-Tamils for their votes. We must thank our Minister of Foreign Affairs, the Hon. Ali Sabry for making a strong statement, condemning and rejecting Justin Trudeaus statement. The Hon. Minister

said that statement was politically motivated, divisive and purely for domestic political consumption in Canada. The Canadian Prime Minister refers to the stories of the Tamil-Canadians affected by the conflict, whom he had met and goes on to say, That is why the Parliament of Canada last year unanimously adopted the Motion to make May 18th the 'Tamil Genocide Remembrance Day . So, that means the Canadian Parliament adopted that Motion of Tamil Genocide because of the stories of Canadian-Tamils and not after any investigation. It is a disgrace that a developed country like Canada comes to serious conclusions such as on genocide without evidence, but merely on hearsay. When talking about genocide, why not Canada commemorate a Canadian genocide day in memory of all the indigenous natives they have killed. The National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls found Canada guilty of genocide! It is unbelievable that Canada, which is preaching human rights to the world, is found guilty of genocide. There have been serious allegations against Canada relating to sexual abuse, starvation of children and forced sterilization of native Indians. All those are well documented unlike the fabrications drummed by the LTTE diaspora against Sri Lanka. When Canada is trying to destroy their indigenous people physically, biologically and psychologically, Sri Lankan Tamils are holding respectable positions in the public and private sectors as well as monopolizing the industrial sector across Sri Lanka.

When talking about this subject, I must mention Ms. Shenali Waduge, who is a good friend of mine. She is an erudite, exceptional writer who conducts an in-depth study before writing articles on any subject. Her articles are very famous especially among patriots. Those are full of correct facts and I would like to thank her for her series of articles on this subject also.

Canada is a created country, Madam. Her history is just 156 years old, which is less than the period the Portuguese ruled some parts of Sri Lanka. They invaded the land that belonged to the native Indians who lived there for many thousand years. Canada should be hiding its head in shame as graves of children emerged to prove beyond any reasonable doubt that the crime of genocide had been committed upon the indigenous natives who lived in Canada before the white man arrived. Also, I must say that Canada, with a history of 156 years, regarded women as persons only in 1929! In one of Shenalis articles, she says, I quote:

In 1916 Alberta Magistrate Emily Murphy to her shock was told by an attorney that her decision was not valid because she was not a 'person' under law. He was referring to the 1867 Section 24 of the British North America Act, ruling 'Women are persons in matters of pains and penalties, but are not persons in matters of rights and privileges'. It took 13 years to change that law.

All women in Canada were given their voting rights only in 1960 whereas Sri Lankan women were granted the right to vote on par with men in 1931 and by 21st of July, 1960, Sri Lanka had produced the worlds first female Prime Minister. So, this is our history and you can see the difference.

Now, all these allegations are for what? That is to establish Eelam in Sri Lanka. India will not allow a separate Tamil State in India and also, Sri Lanka will not allow a separate Tamil eelam in Sri Lanka. Yet, at provincial council level in Canada, Justin Trudeau's overwhelming sympathy for Tamils can be seen.

Canada has approximately 10 million square kilometres of land whereas Sri Lanka has only 65,610 square kilometres. In population density, Canada has four persons per square kilometre whereas Sri Lanka has 341 persons per square kilometre. So, 80 per cent of land in Canada are uninhabited. Therefore, I would ask the Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, if you are really concerned about Tamils, why do you not establish an "eelam" in Canada? The Sri Lankan Tamils do not want an "eelam" in the North because more than 50 per cent of them are living in the South among the Sinhalese. Only the Tamil politicians who are talking here fight for "eelam", that, too, from Colombo, and they also could not get more than 35 per cent votes from the entire Tamil nation. Then, since the white population is reducing in Canada, the Tamils can rule the entire Canada. It would be far better than going after the debt-ridden Sri Lanka. So, that is about that.

Then, there is an issue with the education system in this country. Sri Lanka is a country with a 93 per cent literacy rate. So, why do we not train people to be competent enough to handle these systems? We have spent so much of money, Rs. 16 billion, on a system that cannot be operated and also there are no people who are competent enough to operate the system. So, what are we doing? Parliament adjourned accordingly at 4.57 p.m. until 9.30 a.m. on Wednesday, 24th May, 2023.
Corrections which Members suggest for the Final Print of their speeches should be clearly marked in their copy and
sent to the Editor of HANSARD within two weeks of receipt of the uncorrected copy.
